This morning I found myself feeling grateful for being part of a company like Fixerra . 
Work from home can sometimes feel like youâ€™re not fully in it, the updates donâ€™t always flow the same way, and the work you do isnâ€™t always visible. But that doesnâ€™t mean the contribution is any less.

Thatâ€™s been my view for a while.

Recently, though, I was speaking to a senior professional from a leading broking platform, and they were equally pessimistic on equities â€” stretched valuations, muted 1 year returns. Wealth managers have been circumspect too as the number of outstanding SIPs are reducing.

So hereâ€™s the funny part: ğ˜¦ğ˜·ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜ºğ˜°ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ ğ˜£ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜ªğ˜¦ğ˜·ğ˜¦ğ˜´ ğ˜®ğ˜°ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜º ğ˜¸ğ˜°ğ˜¯â€™ğ˜µ ğ˜¤ğ˜°ğ˜®ğ˜¦ ğ˜µğ˜° ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ğ˜®. Which means someoneâ€™s definitely wrong.

postContent:
Only seven people showed up.

Back at XLRI, I remember choosing an elective that only a few picked â€” Social Entrepreneurship with Prof. Madhukar Shukla.

It wasnâ€™t part of the â€œhotâ€ marketing or finance specialisations, didnâ€™t add much to credits, and certainly didnâ€™t make for glamorous rÃ©sumÃ© points. But something about the idea of business serving more than profit drew me in.

On the first day, the classroom was almost empty â€” just a handful of us. But by the end of that semester, my mind felt fuller than it had in any other course. Prof. Shukla didnâ€™t just teach; he made us live the course. We met social entrepreneurs who had built schools out of nothing, created livelihoods where there was none, and solved problems most of us never even noticed.

One moment that stayed with me was when a rural entrepreneur told us:

â€œThe people I serve donâ€™t need charity. They need a fair chance to stand on their own feet.â€

It hit me â€” impact isnâ€™t about ğ˜¨ğ˜ªğ˜·ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜®ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜¦, itâ€™s about ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜¢ğ˜£ğ˜­ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜®ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜¦.

And in some ways, thatâ€™s what Independence Day is all about too. True freedom isnâ€™t just the absence of restraint â€” itâ€™s the presence of opportunity. And freedom flourishes when we enable others to stand tall.

That small, almost-forgotten elective changed how I think about business, purpose, and responsibility. It made me certain that entrepreneurship can be an act of nation-building â€” one business, one community, one idea at a time.

Happy Independence Day ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³

postContent:
You canâ€™t build great fintech if youâ€™ve never been its customer.

In fintech, there are two kinds of product & tech folks.

Type 1: â€œIâ€™ve seen enough, I know how this works.â€ (Stops at PAN screen when checking any platformâ€™s flow in the fintech ecosystem, assumes the rest is â€˜standard.â€™)

Type 2: â€œLetâ€™s see what happens next.â€ (Does the full KYC, books a â‚¹1,000 FD, applies for a loan or a card theyâ€™ll never take, runs 50 tiny transactionsâ€”just to see the cracks and the magic in that journey/backend.)

The first group imagines the product.
The second group ğ˜§ğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜´ it.

If youâ€™re building fintech and havenâ€™t walked through every stepâ€”on your own platform or others in the ecosystemâ€”youâ€™re almost building blindfolded.

Curiosity isnâ€™t just a trait in fintechâ€”itâ€™s a competitive advantage.
author: Akshar Shah

postContent:
There was a time when just getting a meeting with a bank felt like momentum. Today, even going live isnâ€™t enough :)

At the start, even getting one large fintech, one bank, felt like a win. A guilty kind of happy.

Then, somewhere along the way, you want more.
And you donâ€™t know when it happened â€” gradually, or all at once â€” but the bar moves. Again and again.

Thatâ€™s the startup journey.
You hit one milestone, then quietly raise the bar. You donâ€™t even stop to celebrate.
And sometimes, the ambition, the burn, the chase â€” all of it feels like a lot.
But maybe, amidst all of it, we forget to be thankful.

Thankful for the chance to pursue.

From one person starting Fixerra two and a half years agoâ€¦
â€¦to a team of 20.
â€¦to working with some of the largest platforms and banks in the country.
â€¦to running multiple products â€” and still feeling like itâ€™s just the start.

Still not satisfied. Still hungry.
Maybe weâ€™ve just not paused to look back.

You understand where the trains want to go â€” and build for that.

Consumer facing fintechs too similarly are the real trains and we are merely their digital rails. Our partner platforms are not just our customers, theyâ€™re the blueprint.

Our job is to just keep up the pace, without losing the guardrails.

postContent:
Every entrepreneurâ€™s journey comes with a trade-off:

Bootstrapping builds freedom, but itâ€™s slow.

Funding boosts speed, but adds pressure.

Being visionary inspires, but gets lonely.

Being practical works, but rarely gets praise.

Moving fast feels exciting, but breaks things.

Moving steady feels safe, but might not give you fame. 

Choose your hard.

Build your way.

Culture isnâ€™t just about flexible hours or work life balance.
Itâ€™s about feeling safe, when things go wrong at work or in life.

I told him:Â Iâ€™m not here for volume. Iâ€™m here for the relationship.

At Fixerra, weâ€™ve always believed that partnerships arenâ€™t built on dashboardsâ€”theyâ€™re built on trust.

Weâ€™ve gone through our own early struggles tooâ€”banks asking us for fintechs, and fintechs asking us for bank partners. But we stayed at it, and so did the people who believed in us.

Thatâ€™s why when we sign a new partnerâ€”big or smallâ€”we do it with conviction. That theyâ€™ll make it big. That weâ€™ll grow together. And that Fixerraâ€™s role is to be the enabler behind the scenes.

postContent:
Every day counts in scalable tech. Literally.

Zomatoâ€™s recent earnings call mentioned that YoY growth in food delivery was impacted â€” among other reasons â€” because last year was a leap year and this year had 1 less day in comparison. 

Many found it humorous. But the truth is: itâ€™s actually quite a valid point for any scaled consumer or transaction-tech business.

Think about it: one extra day in a 90-day quarter is ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğŸ­% ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† â€” in orders, transactions. AUM, spends, or users. For platforms like Zomato, or fintechs like us at  Fixerra where every day drives volumes, even a single day can skew growth metrics.

Itâ€™s not an excuse. But it is a reminder â€” At scale, nothing is trivial â€” not even the calendar ğŸ™‚

Two years ago, I visited Kashmir with my family. Amidst the breathtaking beauty, we came across a simple bench with something inscribed in Urdu:

â€œGar firdaus, ruhe zamin ast, hamin asto, hamin asto, hamin ast.â€
(â€œIf there is a paradise on earth, it is this, it is this, it is this.â€)

That quote has stayed with me. And so has the calm, the warmth of the people, and the unmatched beauty of the valley.

Itâ€™s heartbreaking to see such a place disturbed by senseless acts of terror.

Sharing a photo from that visit, in memory of what Kashmir isâ€”and what it deserves to always be.

postContent:
Lately, quite a few people I meet ask me the same question â€”Â "With equity markets being jittery, volumes in FDs and RDs must be picking up, right?"

The answer actually is a Yes.

At  Fixerra, weâ€™ve seen volumes grow steadily over the last few months.

But I donâ€™t believe this surge is just equity money shifting to safer products. It feels more like people are starting to understand the value of asset allocation â€” spreading their investments wisely instead of chasing just one path.

Of course, markets will do what markets do â€” one big rally, and this wisdom might just get forgotten again.

Hopefully, fintech platforms and investment apps will keep encouraging this balanced approach â€” because thatâ€™s what really helps investors in the long run.
author: Akshar Shah

postContent:
Do not stop your SIP! If you thought it was a good time to invest at the peak of the market, it's an even better time to invest when it's 10% down. 

More SIPs were stopped in Jan'25 than started - driven by the market correction, the first for many investors. 

"Asset allocation" has made a come back after 3 years as the latest buzz word in investing. Once again something that should never be stopped. 

Fortunately its 100x easier today to build a wholesome portfolio across stocks, FD, bonds and gold even if you just have 10,000 to invest.

postContent:
How do you know if your customers trust you?

Even tougherâ€”how do you get them to trust you?

In financial services, trust is everything. It doesnâ€™t matter if you have cutting-edge tech, AI, expert support, or the fanciest UIâ€”your survival and success come down to one thing: whether your customers trust you.

But trust isnâ€™t built overnight. It comes from consistency and reliability. One way to earn it is by offering services and products that people have trusted for years. That familiarity creates loyalty, and loyalty keeps customers coming back.

At Fixerra, our goal is simple: we help fintechs launch banking products that build this kind of trust and loyalty.

If youâ€™re a consumer-facing platform, how are you building trust with your customers?
author: Akshar Shah

postContent:
From the very start, I was certain about keeping the team size under 20 at  Fixerra.

Iâ€™m not sure where this idea came from. Maybe itâ€™s because I read somewhere that WhatsApp and Telegram achieved massive success with surprisingly small teams. 

Or maybe when our accountant warned me saying, â€œPost 20 employees, youâ€™ll have to deal with compliance headaches!â€ ğŸ˜„ 

But over time, itâ€™s become more than just a quirky principle. Itâ€™s now a core beliefâ€”to build a lean team that delivers maximum impact.

And hereâ€™s the surprising part: keeping things small hasnâ€™t felt like a constraint. If anything, itâ€™s been an advantage.

With a compact team, we donâ€™t have the bandwidth for endless experiments, and everyone always has something meaningful on their plate. Everyone owns their role and wears multiple hats keeping us nimble and focused.

In the past two years, weâ€™ve done a lotâ€”weâ€™ve pivoted, weâ€™ve failed, weâ€™ve celebrated wins- all with a small team that punches way above its weight.

But sometimes, I genuinely stop and think: "Are these few people really enough to drive the impact weâ€™re aiming for?" And then, I realize the answer is a resounding yes.

As we grow, weâ€™ll hold onto this belief, proving that sometimes, less, truly is more.

And no, Iâ€™m not too obsessed with the 20-member rule. I might consider 21... but only if she/he promises to help us setting up for the additional compliances too. ğŸ˜„
author: Akshar Shah

postContent:
I scored 99.89% in XAT without knowing the exam pattern! 

Itâ€™s funny because I hadnâ€™t even studied for it. When the results came out, I was as surprised as anyone.Â Honestly this was luck more than talent.

Thatâ€™s when I started doing my research, talking to friends and family, and realizing the incredible opportunity in front of me.

After preparing for the interviews, I got into XLRI, and thatâ€™s where my journey truly began. 

It was during my time there that I discovered my interest in finance and cleared first CFA Level too.

I interned at ITC and later received a placement offer. To everyone around me, I was the â€œlucky one.â€ 

But internally, I felt a conflictâ€”I wanted to pursue finance, and ITC's job wasnâ€™t aligned with that vision. I decided to take a leap of faith, rejecting the PPO and giving myself a chance.

In the final round of placements, Kotak came to campus and I converted it.

 At Kotak, I entered wealth management for HNIs and Ultra HNIs, which was completely new territory for me. Two years into it, I vividly remember being handed the personal portfolio of one of Asiaâ€™s wealthiest bankers. 

I was the youngest advisor heâ€™d worked with, and the responsibility was daunting. 

But that challenge became one of the biggest lessons of my career. 

I then transitioned to building Kotak's in-house investment app Kotak Cherry as product lead and that's when I got introduced to the world of fintech.

My time at Kotak Wealth and Kotak Cherry laid the foundation for everything I do today and set the stage for Fixerra.

Turns out, not knowing the exam pattern was the best preparation I could have done. 

Life works in mysterious ways!
author: Akshar Shah

postContent:
One weekâ€™s work in one dayâ€¦

Many fintech partners ask us what the difference is when another TSP like Fixerra has the same banking partner or when they connect directly with the bank or NBFC. What's the edge, the USP, the moat, and all the usual buzzwords ğŸ˜€

I like to share stories to make my point, and today I have another one.

Recently, a large NBFC increased their FD rates, effective today. But it wasnâ€™t a simple rate change â€” it involved different rates based on deposit amounts, even for the same tenure.

It was about a week of work â€” from product to tech to testing. But when you're live with some of the biggest apps and platforms in the country, how do you tell them you'll offer a subpar experience for a week with outdated rates?

This morning, I saw only Fixerra-powered platforms live with the updated rates and amount-based functionality. Huge kudos to our team for pulling this off!

This is where the USP and moat really show up â€” itâ€™s about getting the details right, and making it happen when it counts ğŸ˜ƒ

 Fixerra
